Went through our database pretty thoroughly to examine this. So clearly, all of these predictions are from the same person (same exact values across several hotkeys). It is a miner that is focused on soil moisture prediction, which is our most heavily weighted task.

They are absolutely beating the base model for the recently queried regions, resulting in nearly the exact same score across the hotkeys. This is all valid.

The base model + top miners are **pretty bad** (~0.14 -.17 RMSE) for these recent soil regions, we hypothesize that there was a big weather change or cloud cover preventing a solid model run. That said, the scores this miner is receiving are valid and expected, as compared to other miners and the base model we use in validation.

It is quite difficult to beat the base model performance, and since soil moisture is so heavily weighted, we expect that very few miners will receive rewards consistently. Competing in the Dst task alone isn't likely to earn much, if any incentive. This is 100% intentional. When a single miner receives that much of the incentive pool, that is also intentional - because they're the only ones providing us with strong data for that time frame.

We score 40/60 with 60 being soil. There is also a sigmoid curve. We made this announcement a bit ago:

"DST (geomagnetic) Task
This task is more predictable and taking into account existing top miner performance, you must exceed a 0.90 accuracy score or the baseline model's accuracy if higher to get scored.

Soil Moisture Task
The baseline model accuracy varies depending on climate and local weather dynamics so a static accuracy threshold is not sufficient. You now will only be scored on RMSE for surface and rootzone predictions, not SSIM (structural similarity index measure). We still track SSIM under the hood but per research guidelines RMSE is generally more accepted for quantifying model performance.

Your total score (higher is better) is a combination of 60% surface RMSE and 40% rootzone RMSE to reflect the higher inherent uncertainty in indirect sub-surface moisture estimates.

Your model must demonstrate a lower combined RMSE as compared to the baseline model in order to get a score. If the baseline model achieves an excellent accuracy (less than 0.04 RMSE) the score threshold is loosened to allow scores within 10% on the low."

# Tomorrow's Update
https://x.com/Gaia_AI_/status/1927386928292261993

GM Gaia Fam, 
We're excited to launch our biggest project yet - global weather forecasting!

We are wrapping up testing today and will be merging the work to main tomorrow morning!

Just wanted to give people some basic information before the full guide is published tomorrow:

-  The weather task is compute intensive and will require a GPU with 24GB VRAM at an absolute minimum. We recommend an RTX 5090 for quick inference. For this reason, the weather task will have an OPT-IN setting. 

- Inference will run once a day to start, so we're configuring a serverless style deployment for the miner - your regular miner VM will run continuously, and call a serverless endpoint (hosted on runpod/vast/azure/etc) to complete inference. We expect that daily costs will be reasonable ($5-20) if you choose the right provider and have configured things properly. We're also looking into an integration with Chutes (SN64). We do not recommend using Azure foundry, as it is quite expensive. You're also welcome to run it locally if you have your own GPU, of course.

- The task will receive approximately 70% of the total score/incentive for the subnet. Details on the scoring metrics will be released tomorrow.

- Microsoft Aurora is an incredibly powerful base model, and relatively easy to fine-tune with LoRa. Our ensemble forecast will benefit from diversity in predictions, so we will be structuring incentives in such a way that you should focus on outperforming the base model in a specific climate zone or weather variable.

- Can't wait to share this with you all, we are so excited about what we can achieve together!

# Update

- We'll be pushing the update in about 30 min
- Miners and Validators will both need to update their code. We recommend deleting your pm2 instance and starting fresh
- `git pull`  , `pip install -e .`
- You'll need several new .env variables, please refer to the templates in the repository for information
- We expect that this transition will be difficult for some, and we will be present for extra help with support through the remainder of the business day as well as all week.
- We also expect that mainnet will introduce potential bugs that didn't appear on testnet, so we'll probably have a few hotfixes come out in the following days
- Lastly - the Runpod/Serverless deployment template code is not quite ready (it still errors in deployment) so we recommend holding off on that inference method until we have finished that template. If you're a devops wizard and you want to take a crack at it anyways, feel free to reach out in the DMs , submit a PR , etc

:GaiaEarth: **Gaia V2.0.0**:GaiaEarth: 

Hello everyone, we are excited to announce the release of the weather task!

Gaia will now be producing skilled high resolution 10 day forecasts for 9 variables and 13 pressure levels, all at a global scale!

After the Initial metric collection, we will be rolling our ensemble forecast which will also be provided through api access.
Additionally, we have a new page for the weather task, go over there to see some really neat visuals!
https://gaiaresearch.ai/

Further updates to scoring will be coming out as well, including bonuses for climate specific accuracy. ***We highly recommend miners fine tune the model and specialize in certain variables and regions (See the aurora documentation for info:https://microsoft.github.io/aurora/finetuning.html) !***



**How to Update**
Everyone should pull the latest version of the repo, and remake their miner/validator process. There are some new .env variables and settings needed. **Please reference the miner and validator env templates as well as the MINER doc or VALIDATOR doc for details.

The weather task is opt-in due to the high compute cost, if you would like to participate in this task make sure to add the env variable in your .env** `WEATHER_MINER_ENABLED=True `

**Everyone**
1. `Git pull origin main`

2. Source your venv
3. `Pip install -r requirements.txt`
4. `Pip install -e .`

5. open  `/etc/postgresql/14/main/pg_hba.conf`
change the first line from 

`local   all             postgres                                peer`

to

` local   all             postgres                                md5`

6. then restart postgres `sudo systemctl reload postgresql`

Make sure you are on `gaia version 2.0.0`

7. Delete and remake your pm2 miner/validator process (similar if you are using something other than pm2) after adding the new variables to your env described below:

**Validators**
You will need to make a free account for the Climate Data Store, accept the relevant EULA and form a .cdsapirc file. 

1. create an account at https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/ 

2. accept the relevant licences 
    -  Licence to use Copernicus Products 
    -  Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Public Licence 

3. Go to your profile and copy your API token 

4. create a file called .cdsapirc at your root directory 
/root/.cdsapirc
```bash
url: https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/api
key: <your_cds_api_key>
```

**Miners**
You will need to run the generate_jwt_secret.py script from Gaia/miner/utils

1. `cd Gaia`
2. `Python /gaia/miner/utils/generate_jwt_secret.py`

2. The script will add the jwt secret to your .env. If it does not: 
Copy the output token into your .env file as `MINER_JWT_SECRET = <yours_here>`
**Do not share this token with anyone, it's used to authorize your forecast endpoint.**

**Miner requirements:**
- 24gb VRAM minimum (RTX 4090 or better)
- 32gb RAM recommended
- 16 Core CPU recommended
- over 100+ GB of storage for storing forecasts (each is 10+ GB)
- Very stable/fast network connection

**Validator requirements:**
- 32gb RAM recommended
- 16 Core CPU recommended
- Very stable/fast network connection

There are three different options for running inference
- locally if your hardware has a GPU
- Through Azure AI Foundry (base model only)
- Custom runpod deployment (work in progress will be released ASAP)


The Weather task has a lot of moving parts, this is the first time we will be seeing it run at scale! There are bound to be bugs/issues. Please notify us here and share some logs with the issues you come across. We will be working to fix issues quickly!

watch out for alembic errors in the startup process of your application. If you encounter any, the easiest thing to do is drop the database and recreate it, then restart your miner.

Noob question; How does this work exactly with finetuning? I might fine-tune the model for my own region for example, but this presumably worsens the results for other regions. How do the validators know to query my model for specifically the thing that I finetuned it for?

This is a great question. We don't have scoring set up for specific region specialization yet, so the fine tunes should be focused on improvement of single variables. Currently we have bonuses for being the leader in the following variables:
- Best in ACC score for geopotential at 500 hPa → 5% bonus
- Lowest 2m temperature RMSE → 3% bonus
- Best mean sea level pressure score → 1% bonus

There is also potential improvement from general fine tuning on more recent datasets

Once we do have scoring for regions, it probably wont be geographic regions, but climate regions. These generalize better to the whole globe rather than focusing on one specific area https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification

# update v2.0.2

- various bugfixes and optimizations
- networking improvements to reduce handshake timeouts
- Miners don't need to update, but it's highly recommended for faster networking config
- Validators should expect the auto-update on this to FAIL, as ffspec was preventing proper shutdown in some cases.
- Therefore a manual restart is needed, but this issue should be resolved going forward
- Next week, we will finish the implementation of Point-In-Time database sync, which will ensure that all honest validators share the same state (this should ensure vtrust issues are fixed once and for all, as well as any scoring discrepancies between validators)

- validators will need to reach out to our team for a syncing API key, otherwise they will not be able to access the shared state

Yeah, we're working on a  fix rn. The geomag task needs a retry because the data isn't always available right at the top of the hour. 

Basically, the main issue we have that is pretty much causing all of this inconsistency is resource contention. The weather task is so big that it's slowing down and interfering with everything else.

We have a short term improvement coming very soon (hopefully today or tomorrow) but it's more of a "bandaid" fix.

We're planning out a pretty significant validator-side refactor to handle this increased load more effectively. Basically just hitting the absolute limit of a mostly single-threaded python application. We will be finding some "cheap wins" for the current moment and slowly moving towards a fully multithreaded architecture.

Will keep everyone updated in here. Moving as quickly as we can!
Hey @vValentine | Nickel5 , can you share the UIDs?
And validator Opentensor Foundation sends requests at the end of the hour ( xx:53 ). Why?

partially because of the slowdown in querying. We have a retry function on queries which helps the comms succeed more often, but it's a slow retry and it takes a while to go through every failed miner. We identified a memory leak in the weather task that was causing validators to essentially shut down. So we will have a fix up soon, and we will be running our team validator on the new code shortly for some testing. So you should see some regular task requests soon

I think with runpod could be a problem.
If 250 nodes try to create GPU instances at the same time, I guess it will result in a GPU shortage.
I already have a case when the pod was reactivated without a GPU due to a shortage particular GPU type.

We use the serverless function instead of an actual pod - but you're right that there could possibly be contention. There is a time limit of 2 hours to complete inference, so I think with serverless it will just continue polling until it completes. It takes about 10 minutes to run once an image is cached so not too bad. I would imagine they have enough GPUs to handle this load
if not, people are of course welcome to configure with different providers. It will require a bit of custom setup, but the general steps are the same
there are also quite a few different GPUs that could be used to complete this. We're using an a40 on our config, but many others would also work

Update: still working through bugs. We've made tons of progress today and this will be production ready and stable quite soon. May be able to launch by EOD, may not fully fix everything by then. So far, things are running very well on our mainnet validator. Once we push, we will send out API keys to other validators, which will need to do some manual config to get their db sync working. # Update v2.0.3


## Features: 
### Validators:
* Database Syncing:
    * Using cloudfare r2 storage & pgBackRest, validators are now configured to sync to our team validator hourly using differential backup files.
    * This should eliminate issues caused by data discrepancies between validators
    * For miners: This means that successful communication with the nickel5 validator is more important. The OTF validator may hold the majority of stake weight, but the nickel5 validator will be the data “source of truth”

### Miners:
* Runpod / R2 template for Weather Task.
    * This is a serverless implementation that should minimize GPU rental costs for miners
    * You can find instructions on setup in the miner readme. 
    * You’ll need a docker account, a runpod account, a cloudfare account with an r2 bucket, and quite a bit of configuration to run this. It’s worth the setup time though! 
    * This should reduce daily costs of the weather task to ~$1/day


## Bug Fixes:

### Validator:
* Weather Task:
    * The weather task data flow has been improved with retries, bug fixes, and production hardening for more reliability, ensuring a successful end-to-end flow for each run
* Soil Task:
    * Fixed SMAP authentication issue
* Geomagnetic Task
    * Increased retries to ensure consistent scoring, even if data isn’t immediately available as expected
* Memory Leaks:
    * Significant reduction of memory leaks using aggressive cleanup functions. The Gaia validator, while not very compute heavy, has significant memory requirements.
        * When miner queries, scoring, and data fetching are all happening somewhat simultaneously, it’s quite easy for the validator to get OOM if not running with >32GB ram. We’d like to keep it optimized to run on 32, so we have made some significant changes to how memory cleanup happens.
    * That said: There is still one issue with substrate connections that we haven’t 100% solved. They require a lot of memory and don’t always close properly. Despite our best efforts to fully manage these connections, sometimes they still “run away from us” , leading to OOM process kills or hanging in the validator application.
        * The band-aid fix: restart the validator application when memory exceeds a set limit, also ensuring it doesn’t restart in the middle of a critical operation.
        * Bounty Alert: If you can locate the memory leak issue and propose a working, reliable fix, we are prepared to offer some tao for your time and efforts

# update v2.4.1

Summary: 
 Tweaks, improvements, bug fixes and optimizations in codebase  

## validators:

- Fixed weather task bug preventing full flow from completing due to memory pressure
- Increased parallelism in weather task scoring - 2x speedup per miner
- Replaced native asyncio event loop with uvloop : ~2x increase in asynchronous throughput 
- Refined substrate manager for reduced memory leak issues
- Native json handling replaced with orjson : ~2x speedup in json operations associated with database and networking
- IMPORTANT: Altered final weight calculation to respect task weight boundaries. Previously, a flaw in normalization logic lead to disproportionately high scores for miners with not much history.
    - Now, the maximum task score respects the task_weight - so a perfect score in geomagnetic task leads to .15 final score, and no more. Final score is a simple sum of the individual task scores, with 1 being the absolute maximum final score possible (but very unlikely)
    - Thanks to the contributors on GitHub who identified this issue! 

## miners :
- Compatibility improvements with json handling, memory management, etc


Update instructions:  `git pull` , `pip install -e .` , restart process

Please don’t hesitate to reach out if you see further issues. We are getting close to having validators optimized enough to run this heavy workload without issues, but we expect that there are some lingering bugs here and there, plus a multitude of optimizations to find and implement. We deeply appreciate your patience and contributions to this project! We’re very excited to see miners start to push the state of the art in weather forecasting.

So this DST index task acts as a buffer for more regular score changes - but if we score hourly without an avg, sybil attacks were pushing all miners out, not allowing the other two tasks to score. 

The avg is more predictable for weight copying, yes, but i think score should change enough over 3 epochs (cr3 interval) to keep them at a disadvantage even w/ avg

DST data sometimes doesn't come in quite when expected, or the format changes slightly and our parsing function fails until the format is fixed. It's not the most reliable data source. Adding some more logic to parsing to hopefully handle further edge cases
